newsitem.title: USA: INTERVIEW/Zenith tries again on Internet TV.
newsitem.headline: INTERVIEW/Zenith tries again on Internet TV.

text.p: Zenith Electronics Corp, after a false start, is taking a second stab at an Internet television product, adding new partners and a new platform, Chief Executive Officer Peter Willmott told Reuters.

The company last May announced that it would collaborate with Diba Inc, the Menlo Park, Calif.-based software company to collaborate on interactive television technology to let viewers surf the Internet on their TV sets.
However, Zenith failed to deliver a product in time for the 1996 Christmas selling season, and Willmott said none is imminent from the Diba collaboration.

Zenith on Wednesday said it made alliances to launch new Internet television products with Network Computer Inc, a unit of Oracle Corp, and with Navio Communications Inc, the consumer affiliate of Netscape Communications Corp.

"We still have a relationship with Diba, but the platform we have today is our central driving force," Willmott said in a telephone interview on the eve of the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas. He declined to quantify the investment Zenith has made in Diba.
"We have come up with partners that provide a great platform for future growth in this segment of the business," Willmott said.
"We'll move very quickly, since we were slow to get a product to market," Willmott said, noting the new Internet TV products are scheduled for market introduction "in the latter half of 1997."
He would not discuss price. Analysts expect the hardware could add $600 to the cost of a large-screen television. The devices will include set-top boxes, which sell for less than $500.
Diba vice president Joe Gillach told Reuters, "We delivered a piece of the product to Zenith, which has to assemble many into a solution. It takes more than one company to supply all the pieces."
Gillach, who said Zenith is a major investor in Diba, added his company would take a "wait and see" posture on the direction of its future involvement with Zenith.

Willmott said Zenith's restructuring program, announced in December, was on track. In a move to accelerate its return to profitability, the company is cutting its U.S. workforce by more than 25 percent.
Willmott also said plans for a proposed $100 million large-screeen picture tube plant in suburban Woodridge, Ill. remained "on hold."
Zenith's last full year of profitability was 1988.
